metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.8 runoff observation system of Gaotai  bridge on the Heihe River, 2013)
metadata.description:
The No. 8 hydrological section is located at Gaotai Heihe River Bridge (N39° 23′22.93 ″, E 99° 49′37.29″, 1347 m a.s.l.)  in the midstream of the Heihe River Basin, Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The dataset contains observations recorded by the No.8 hydrological section from 17 June, 2012, to 31 December, 2013. The width of this section is 210 meters. The water level was measured using an SR50 ultrasonic range and the discharge was measured using cross-section reconnaissance by the StreamPro ADCP. The dataset includes the following parameters: water level (recorded every 30 minutes) and discharge. The missing and incorrect (outside the normal range) data were replaced with -6999.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), He et al. (2016) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'oasis–desert interaction' in the context of eco-hydrological research?
Definition.Answer: In eco-hydrological research, 'oasis–desert interaction' refers to the study of exchanges and dynamics between oasis and desert systems, including energy, water vapor, and carbon interactions. This interaction is crucial for maintaining ecological balance and supporting sustainable development in arid and semi-arid areas, particularly by observing the balance and dynamics between these contrasting ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using eddy covariance towers compare to that of automatic meteorological stations in terms of capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance towers are used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, which provide detailed information on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. In contrast, automatic meteorological stations collect hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, with a 10-minute average period. Both methods offer complementary insights, but eddy covariance towers focus more on flux exchanges, while meteorological stations provide broader environmental context.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality control procedures between multiscale datasets obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research and long-term oasis-desert system datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The multiscale datasets from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. In contrast, the long-term oasis-desert system datasets emphasize a procedure divided into data collection, processing, and archiving and sharing, with a focus on ensuring consistent quality over an extended period from 2012 to 2021.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of obtaining multiscale observations in oasis-desert systems compare to those faced in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis-desert systems, the primary challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations needed to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. In contrast, inland river basins face ecological degradation challenges, such as drying rivers and vegetation degradation, which complicate the collection of hydrological and ecological data needed to address these environmental issues.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed patterns of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data inform the sustainability strategies for oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns provide critical insights into the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is essential for sustainable development. By quantifying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, researchers can better understand the oasis-desert interactions, crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development. This understanding is vital for achieving goals like carbon neutrality and ecological security in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for hierarchically nested scales in capturing eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, necessitating the use of hierarchically nested scales to capture these processes effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable development in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieve sustainable development because oases are essential for ecological stability and economic development, supporting more than 90% of the population in arid regions despite comprising less than 10% of the area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenge of ecological environment degradation in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins face degradation due to factors such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, especially in regions like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the implementation of hierarchical instrumentation networks affect the quality and availability of data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The implementation of hierarchical instrumentation networks could enhance the quality and availability of data by facilitating continuous and intensive observations across multiple scales. This can improve the understanding of hydrometeorological processes and provide reliable datasets for assessing ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in oasis-desert areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the lack of long-term multiscale observations in understanding oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The absence of long-term multiscale observations may hinder the quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems, which is crucial for recognizing interactions and maintaining ecological balance. This could negatively impact efforts towards ecological security and sustainable development, as well as strategies for carbon neutrality and peaking.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the aim of employing a multiscale observation system in the collection of eco-hydrological data in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The aim of employing a multiscale observation system is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data. This approach is intended to provide comprehensive insights into oasis-desert interactions and support sustainable development in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a focus on understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems is crucial to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, maintain ecological stability, and support the socioeconomic development of oases. This understanding is significant for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and protecting the ecological environment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale observations integrated into datasets for eco-hydrological research in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale observations are integrated into datasets by using a combination of a flux observation matrix including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network; and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. These instruments are organized in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. Additionally, synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes are included to enrich the dataset.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and observation systems enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilizes a flux observation matrix consisting of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, along with an eco-hydrological sensor network and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in airborne remote sensing technologies facilitate the collection of detailed observational data in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers allow for comprehensive airborne remote sensing missions, enabling detailed data collection over complex landscapes like oasis-desert systems.

Enablement.Question: What strategies are implemented to ensure quality control and data accuracy in long-term eco-hydrological observations?
Enablement.Answer: Data quality control is ensured through careful sensor calibration, robust data collection processes, and meticulous data processing and archiving, as demonstrated in the collection of hydrometeorological and flux data from automatic weather stations and eddy covariance systems.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in ensuring the quality and consistency of multiscale eco-hydrological data collection, and how can they be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. The data are carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Expectation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in obtaining comprehensive datasets for inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, and what strategies could be employed to overcome these?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms. Strategies to overcome these challenges include establishing a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the challenges faced in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, and how could data collection be enhanced to support sustainable development?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial, particularly in the face of ecological degradation. Challenges include river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and desertification. Enhanced data collection could involve long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges using advanced remote sensing technologies and increased ground-based observations to provide more accurate and timely data to inform sustainable development practices.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges associated with acquiring multiscale observations in heterogeneous surfaces.
Assertion.Answer: One of the significant challenges is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hampers progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes across heterogeneous surfaces. To address this, hierarchically nested scales and intensive observation periods are employed to obtain comprehensive data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from oasis-desert areas are processed and quality-controlled before being made available.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets from oasis-desert areas undergo a rigorous procedure that includes sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and quality control measures. This ensures high-quality data that are freely available, such as those from the HiWATER project, which are accessible through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges in maintaining long-term data quality and consistency for datasets capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term data quality and consistency include ecological environment degradation such as land desertification, drying rivers, and vegetation degradation. Consistent data quality control must be implemented through sensor calibration, data processing, and dataset generation and sharing. Long-term observations are crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological stability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please conduct a search for potential datasets that can be used to study hydrometeorological processes in arid regions, focusing on integrating eco-hydrological and vegetation dynamics data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include those derived from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) which encompass a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. These datasets provide information on soil moisture, leaf area index, and vegetation dynamics. Additionally, datasets from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center offer long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data, supplemented with vegetation and soil parameters.
